Message.Title: 787 cost 30 billion, profit margin is 5% what is the break even point ?
Message.Msg: Boeing key statistics lists Boeing profit margin at 5% , the 787 is a 30 billion dollar cost plane , not the original SPEEA offered cost of 5 billion dollars. The retails sales price for a 787 on the high side, is 150 million per plane. Now, do the math and tell me how many planes need to be made to break even! How many years at 10 per month would that take here is 30 billion 30,000.000.000 and here is 5% of 30 billion 1,500,000,000 so where is the break even point at 10 planes per month if nothing goes wrong 5% of 150 million is a profit per plane of $750,000That is why Airbus stock is up 159% in the past 5 years and Boeing stock is up 39% and most of that is stock buy back it is a spike .

Topic.Title: 787 cost 30 billion, profit margin is 5% what is the break even point ?

Message.Title: Health law led to $2.1 billion in savings for consumers
Message.Msg: A new report estimates that U.S. consumers who purchase their own health insurance saved $2.1 billion last year due to tougher rules in the federal healthcare law. Thursday's report by the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation estimates that individual premiums would have been $1.9 billion higher in 2012 without the requirements in the federal Affordable Care Act. In addition, the nonprofit group said individual policyholders nationwide should receive $241 million in rebates this summer. Insurers must issue rebates to individuals and small businesses if they don't spend at least 80% of their annual premiums on medical care. QUIZ: How much do you know about healthcare? This week, The Times reported that Blue Shield of California owes $24.5 million in rebates to thousands of small firms, and Anthem Blue Cross owes $12 million to some small businesses in the state. These rebates and additional amounts coming from other insurers must be paid by Aug. 1.

Message.Title: Cheapest Commie Care Plan will cost 20K for Family of /Four or Five
Message.Msg: The cheapest Obamacare health insurance plan will cost a family $20,000 per year. Americans will be forced to purchase the plan or face the Obama IRS. CNS News reported: In a final regulation issued Wednesday, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) assumed that under Obamacare the cheapest health insurance plan available in 2016 for a family will cost $20,000 for the year. Under Obamacare, Americans will be required to buy health insurance or pay a penalty to the IRS. The IRS’s assumption that the cheapest plan for a family will cost $20,000 per year is found in examples the IRS gives to help people understand how to calculate the penalty they will need to pay the government if they do not buy a mandated health plan. The examples point to families of four and families of five, both of which the IRS expects in its assumptions to pay a minimum of $20,000 per year for a bronze plan. “The annual national average bronze plan premium for a family of 5 (2 adults, 3 children) is $20,000,” the regulation says.

"The final electoral college count gave President Obama a wide 332 to 206 margin over Romney. 270 electoral college votes are needed to win the Presidency. Romney lost New Hampshire’s 4 electoral college votes by a margin of 40,659. Obama won with 368,529 to Romney’s 327,870. Romney lost Florida’s 29 electoral college votes by a margin of 73,858. Obama won with 4,236,032 to Romney's 4,162,174. Romney lost Ohio’s 18 electoral college votes by a margin of 103,481. Obama won with 2,697,260 to Romney’s 2,593,779 Romney lost Virginia’s 13 electoral college votes by a margin of 115,910. Obama won with 1,905,528 to Romney’s 1,789,618. Add the 64 electoral college votes from this switch of 333,908 votes in these four key states to Romney’s 206, remove them from Obama’s 332, and Romney defeats Obama 270 to 268. Overall, voter turnout was down, from 131 million in 2008 to 122 million in 2012. Obama won 7.6 million fewer votes than he did in 2008, and Romney won 1.3 million fewer than McCain in 2008."

Topic.Title: 787 cost 30 billion, profit margin is 5% what is the break even point ?

Message.Msg: Latest production cost estimate on the 787 from Forbes is $200M. Average selling price is $115M. Production costs have not been coming down like they were supposed to and it isn't clear that Boeing will ever get them down to less than $115M which isn't surprising given the way they were designed and the higher than expected tolerance variations with the composite parts. Breakeven is going to be a long way down the road. I've got a buy on the stock because of the technical action of the stock and the high profit margins on the 737, 777, and government programs but eventually Boeing is going to have to deal with their inability to make a profit on composite airplanes.

Topic.Title: 787 cost 30 billion, profit margin is 5% what is the break even point ?

Message.Msg: Even at $7.5 million, that is alot of planes to recoup $30B(if the $30B is correct which would be nearly impossible to verify or how they ammoritize it). What is more scarey if it were my money is the lost interest that could have been earned with the non-recurring cost to develop the plane. Spares and maintaince profits will play a big part of breaking even, that is where the recurring income is in the airplane business.
